Geography of Danger

Spatial Patterns in Aid Worker Attacks (1997–2024)

Global Heatmap: Where Aid Workers Are Most at Risk

This interactive map shows incident concentrations from 1997–2024. Darker regions reflect higher risk for humanitarian operations (Outcomes 2023).

Conflict Typologies & Field Realities

Humanitarian threats often reflect political environments:

  1. Post-9/11 War Zones
    Afghanistan, Iraq, and Pakistan saw spikes due to blurred civil-military boundaries and insurgency targeting (Event Data Project (ACLED) 2023).

  2. African Civil Wars
    80% of victims are national staff; aid is blocked or weaponized during unrest (e.g., South Sudan, Sudan, Mali) ((MSF) 2017).

  3. State Collapse
    Syria and Haiti show how lawless zones foster gang/warlord rule and complex violence (News 2023).

  4. Authoritarian Crackdowns
    Myanmar and Ethiopia restrict aid legally or violently post-2021 (Outcomes 2023).

  5. Spillover Conflicts
    Border insecurity drives attacks in Kenya, Cameroon, and Uganda (UNHCR 2022).

Animated Globe of Aid Worker Attacks (1997–2024)

This animated globe presents a dynamic view of where humanitarian workers have been most at risk over the last three decades.

  • Early hotspots emerge across East Africa and Central Asia in the late 1990s.
  • By the mid-2000s, incidents surge in Iraq, Sudan, and DR Congo — coinciding with conflict escalation and UN deployments.
  • In the 2010s, the rise of ISIS, Syrian civil war, and Yemen crisis shift the map eastward.
  • By 2020–2024, the globe shows intensified activity in Afghanistan, Palestine, and Myanmar, reflecting modern frontline risk.

The orthographic projection emphasizes global curvature — making regional clusters and geographic escalation patterns easier to observe as the world spins forward in time.

Case Study Highlights

Afghanistan (#1 in Attacks)
- 142 attacks on female aid workers (2021–2023)
- 38% of attacks post-Taliban resurgence targeted women
- 60% decline in women-led operations (English 2021)

Haiti (#16 in Attacks)
- Gangs control 80% of Port-au-Prince
- 70+ convoy attacks; 400% rise in kidnappings
- Aid presence has retreated from 60% of zones (News 2023)

The Cartography of Risk

  1. Power Vacuum Targeting
    73% of attacks cluster after regime change (e.g., Afghanistan, Haiti).

  2. Weaponized Access
    Aid is deliberately blocked or attacked — a new form of strategic denial (Red Cross (ICRC) 2023).

  3. Climate-Conflict Nexus
    The Sahel, Ethiopia, and Sudan face layered crises of drought and violence (UNHCR 2022).

“We’re not just mapping where attacks happen…

but where the concept of humanitarian neutrality is under assault.”

— Humanitarian Security Annual Report 2024 (Outcomes 2023)
